name: Design Thinking
description: A human-centered approach to innovation that draws from the designer's toolkit to integrate the needs of people, the possibilities of technology, and the requirements for business success.
steps: Empathize: Understand user needs through observation and engagement
Define: Create a clear problem statement based on user needs
Ideate: Brainstorm potential solutions
Prototype: Build representations of potential solutions
Test: Test prototypes with users and refine
tips: Focus on understanding user needs before jumping to solutions
Embrace diverse perspectives in your team
Don't be afraid to fail early and often
Use time constraints to maintain momentum

name: Lean Startup
description: A methodology for developing businesses and products that aims to shorten product development cycles by adopting a combination of business-hypothesis-driven experimentation and iterative product releases.
steps: Build: Create a Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
Measure: Gather data on customer interactions
Learn: Use data to validate or invalidate hypotheses
Pivot or Persevere: Make strategic changes based on learnings
tips: Focus on validated learning over intuition
Use actionable metrics instead of vanity metrics
Test one hypothesis at a time
Get out of the building and talk to customers
references: The Lean Startup by Eric Ries

name: Business Model Canvas
description: A strategic management template for developing new or documenting existing business models, allowing companies to visualize and assess their value proposition, infrastructure, customers, and finances.
steps: Define Customer Segments
Articulate Value Propositions
Identify Channels
Establish Customer Relationships
Determine Revenue Streams
List Key Resources
Outline Key Activities
Identify Key Partners
Calculate Cost Structure
tips: Start with the customer and work outward
Use different colors for different customer segments
Test assumptions for each component
Iterate based on feedback
references: Business Model Generation by Alexander Osterwalder

name: SCAMPER
description: A creative thinking framework that uses a set of directed questions to help generate new ideas for products, services, or processes by modifying existing ones.
steps: Substitute: What can you substitute in your product or process?
Combine: What elements can you combine?
Adapt: What can you adapt from somewhere else?
Modify/Magnify/Minimize: What can you modify, magnify, or minimize?
Put to other uses: What other uses might your product or process have?
Eliminate: What can you eliminate or reduce?
Reverse/Rearrange: What can you reverse or rearrange?
tips: Focus on one SCAMPER element at a time
Use visual thinking to support the process
Apply to both physical products and intangible services
Encourage wild ideas before filtering

name: Customer Journey Mapping
description: A visual representation of the customer's experience with a product or service over time and across different channels, highlighting their needs, pain points, and emotions.
steps: Define scope and customer personas
List all customer touchpoints
Map the current journey chronologically
Add customer thoughts, feelings, and pain points
Identify moments of truth and opportunities
Develop solutions for key pain points
Create an ideal future state journey
tips: Base your map on real customer research, not assumptions
Include both digital and physical touchpoints
Use photos, quotes, and visuals to bring the journey to life
Review and update the map regularly
references: This is Service Design Thinking by Marc Stickdorn

name: Value Proposition Canvas
description: A framework for ensuring product-market fit by mapping customer needs and desires against your value proposition, helping to identify gaps and opportunities.
benefits: Aligns product features with customer needs
steps: Create customer profile: jobs, pains, and gains
Map value proposition: products/services, pain relievers, and gain creators
Analyze the fit between customer profile and value proposition
Identify gaps and opportunities
Refine the value proposition to better address customer needs
Test and iterate based on customer feedback
tips: Start with the customer profile before developing the value map
Be specific about customer jobs, pains, and gains
Rank items by importance to customers
Test your assumptions with real customers
references: Value Proposition Design by Alexander Osterwalder

name: Empathy Mapping
description: A collaborative visualization tool used to articulate what we know about a particular type of user, helping teams build empathy and a shared understanding of user needs.
steps: Define the user/customer segment to focus on
Map what the user Says (quotes, statements)
Map what the user Thinks (beliefs, values, concerns)
Map what the user Does (actions, behaviors)
Map what the user Feels (emotions, sensations)
Identify user needs, goals, and pain points
Generate insights and opportunities based on the map
tips: Focus on one user segment at a time
Use real user data rather than assumptions
Be specific and use direct quotes where possible
Update the map as you learn more about your users

name: Five Whys
description: An iterative interrogative technique used to explore the cause-and-effect relationships underlying a particular problem by repeatedly asking 'why' to drill down to the root cause.
benefits: Identifies root causes rather than symptoms
steps: Clearly define the problem statement
Ask 'Why did this happen?' for the problem
For each answer, ask 'Why?' again
Continue asking 'Why?' at least five times
Identify when you've reached the root cause
Develop countermeasures or solutions
Implement and monitor solutions
tips: Focus on processes and systems, not people
Be careful not to stop at symptoms
Use evidence and data, not assumptions
The number five is a guideline, not a rule - stop when you've found the root cause
references: Taiichi Ohno (pioneer of the Toyota Production System)

name: Jobs to be Done
description: A framework for understanding customer motivation by focusing on the 'job' they're trying to get done, rather than their demographics or product attributes, to drive innovation and improve product-market fit.
benefits: Focuses on customer motivation, not just demographics
Generates insights for marketing and positioning
steps: Identify the context in which customers use your product
Conduct customer interviews focused on their 'jobs'
Map the functional, emotional, and social dimensions of the job
Identify the hiring and firing criteria for solutions
Define job statements in the format: 'When [situation], I want to [motivation], so I can [expected outcome]'
Prioritize jobs based on importance and satisfaction
Design solutions that address high-priority, underserved jobs
tips: Focus on the job, not the customer or the solution
Look for workarounds as indicators of unmet needs
Consider both functional and emotional aspects of the job
Use the switch interview technique to understand why customers 'hired' your solution
references: Competing Against Luck by Clayton Christensen
Jobs to be Done: Theory to Practice by Anthony Ulwick

name: Brainstorming
description: A group creativity technique designed to generate a large number of ideas for solving a specific problem by encouraging participants to build on each other's suggestions and delaying criticism.
benefits: Generates a high volume of ideas quickly
steps: Define the problem or challenge clearly
Set ground rules (no criticism, wild ideas welcome, quantity over quality)
Generate ideas individually for 5-10 minutes
Share ideas with the group in rounds
Build on others' ideas
Record all ideas visibly
Group and categorize similar ideas
Vote or prioritize ideas
tips: Defer judgment during the ideation phase
Encourage quantity over quality initially
Build on other people's ideas ('yes, and...')
Set a specific time limit to maintain energy
Consider using a facilitator to enforce rules
